docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Amy S. Grossberg and Brian C. Peterson are certainly responsible for the death of their child and will have to live with the memory of this horror for the rest of their lives (front page, July 10). But I doubt that Ms. Grossberg behaved as she did because ''an egocentricity'' blinded her to the need to seek help, as Judge Henry duPont Ridgely stated while sentencing her to 30 months in prison. Ms. Grossberg, not yet 20 years old, frightened and overwhelmed by the thought of her mother finding out about her pregnancy, used extremely poor judgment and panicked. She felt so alone that she was unable to allow herself to be supported by anyone who could have counseled her on other options, like legal adoption or an abortion. Perhaps a lesson can be learned from this: parents and children need to have open communication. SUSAN SCHEER New York, July 10, 1998

headline.main: Abortion Bill Won't Encourage Teen-Agers to Reach Out to Parents

docs.abstract: Susan Scheer letter, responding to July 10 article on sentencing of Amy S Grossberg, comments on need for open communication between parents and children

docs.lead_paragraph: Federal judges around the country, frustrated by cases in which patients denied medical benefits have no right to sue, are urging Congress to consider changes in a 1974 law that protects insurance companies and health maintenance organizations against legal attacks. In their decisions, the judges do not offer detailed solutions of the type being pushed in Congress by Democrats and some Republicans. But they say their hands are tied by the 1974 law, the Employee Retirement Income Security Act. And they often lament the results, saying the law has not kept pace with changes in health care and the workplace.

headline.main: Hands Tied, Judges Rue Law That Limits H.M.O. Liability

docs.abstract: Federal judges around nation, frustrated by cases in which patients improperly denied medical benefits by employer-sponsored health plans have no right to sue for resulting damages, are urging Congress to weigh changes in 1974 law that shields insurers and health maintenance organizations against liability suits; complain Employee Retirement Income Security Act has not kept pace with changes in health care and workplace; law established uniform Federal standards to spur employers to provide benefit (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Denouncing Amy S. Grossberg for egocentric indifference to the life of her newborn son, a Delaware judge sentenced her today to 30 months in prison for contributing to the baby's death in November 1996. Minutes later, the judge, Henry duPont Ridgely, issued a gentler scolding to Ms. Grossberg's co-defendant and former high school sweetheart, Brian C. Peterson, and gave him a two-year sentence. To Ms. Grossberg, the judge said, ''If there's a disturbing aspect to your character, an unsettling trait as the time of childbirth neared, it was an egocentricity that blinded you to the need to seek help and to the intrinsic value of the life of the child.''

headline.main: Teen-Agers Get Terms in Prison In Baby's Death

docs.abstract: Judge Henry duPont Ridgely sentences Amy S Grossberg to 30 months in prison and her former boyfriend, Brian C Peterson, to two-year sentence for contributing to death of their newborn baby in Newark, Del, in November 1996; Grossberg's lawyer renews old arguments that baby was stillborn; infant was found in Dumpster behind motel where couple went when Grossberg went into labor; prosecutors concede they could not prove that fractures on newborn's head had been deliberately inflicted or who had caused them; judge denounces Grossberg for egocentric indifference to life of her newborn son, and issues gentler scolding to Peterson, who had urged Grossberg to seek abortion or go to hospital; Grossberg and Peterson grew up in New Jersey and were 18-year-old college freshmen at time of birth; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Andy Pettitte's cut fastball is breaking bats again, his slider is sharper and he is throwing pitches precisely where he wants to throw them. But to Pettitte, these are merely symptoms of his comeback from an early season slump. The cure, he is sure, was the reunion of his family.

headline.main: Pettitte Makes Sure Yanks Stay In Stride

docs.lead_paragraph: A dispute between women's groups and the Vatican over a legal term has broadened into a battle of religion and gender politics that could jeopardize agreement on whether rape will be declared a war crime by an international criminal court. There is wide consensus at a United Nations conference that rape is a war crime that should be prosecuted by an international tribunal. Women's groups have fought to have a treaty include ''enforced pregnancy'' as a war crime, for the act of impregnating women and forcing them to bear children as tools of ethnic reprisal, as in the case of forcing Croatian women to have Serbian babies.

headline.main: Semantics Stalls Pact Labeling Rape a War Crime

docs.abstract: Agreement on declaring rape a war crime by international criminal court is being jeopardized by dispute between women's groups and Vatican over legal term; at issue is term 'enforced pregnancy,' which women's groups have fought to have included in treaty; Vatican agrees that rapes are war crimes, but fears term 'enforced pregnancy' could be broadly interpreted as invitation to challenge anti-abortion laws in many countries; battle has become one of most glaring and painful examples of how contentious and intractible process of negotiating treaty on war crimes is (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A large study has found that women's walking during labor has no effect on labor and delivery. ''Like many issues where there are very opposing views, the truth was in the middle,'' said the director of the study, Dr. Steven L. Bloom of the University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center in Dallas.

headline.main: Study Neutral About Walking During Labor

docs.abstract: Large study finds that women's walking during labor has no effect on labor and delivery; study grew out of efforts to reduce number of Caesarean sections; results of study are published in The New England Journal of Medicine (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 Nigeria's Leader Pleads for Calm Nigeria's military ruler agreed to allow outside experts to take part in the autopsy on the opposition leader Moshood K. O. Abiola and spoke in vague terms of moving the country toward democracy. His statements were intended to soothe public anger after Mr. Abiola's sudden death. Sporadic rioting has left at least 19 people dead. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: During her lifetime and for a good 25 years after her death in 1954, Frida Kahlo seemed to owe much of her renown as a painter to the fact that she was married to Diego Rivera, the colossus of Mexican muralism. Not that Rivera did not himself proclaim her a great artist in her own right. It is just that for decades the shadow of Rivera's painting, personality and politics served to dim most other Mexican lights. But by the early 1980's, the Socialist Realism of Rivera's vast historical and revolutionary murals had begun to look outdated. Coincidentally, Kahlo was being rediscovered as an artist whose unflinching portrayal of her own physical and emotional pain spoke not only to a new generation of feminists but also to an era more concerned with feeling than ideology.

headline.main: Arts Abroad; Frida Kahlo Introduces Her Husband, Diego Rivera

docs.abstract: Alan Riding article on Frida Kahlo, feminist icon, and her husband, Mexican muralist Diego Rivera, in light of exhibition of their art at Musee Maillol in Paris; photos (L)
